sub.page.title: Geometric Properties of the Cross Products: Illustration

block.para: The geometric properties of the cross product operation are used widely. The following illustrations may help you understand them well.

Direction of the cross product vector Given two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y}, their cross product is perpendicular to both \Vect{x} and \Vect{y}. Moreover, the ordered triple (\Vect{x},\Vect{y},\CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} }) represents the right hand orientation of \RNr[3].

These two properties combined determine the direction of the cross product vector. (If \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} are parallel, then their cross product vanishes.) Thus the only information we are missing about the cross product vector is its length ...
Length of the cross product vector The length of \CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} } satisfies
So it is determined by the length of \Vect{x}, the length of \Vect{y}, and the angle between them. So it is equal to the area of the parallelogram spanned by \Vect{x} and \Vect{y}.

Recall now that the area of a parallelogram is the product of base length and its height. Then the following image explains why the area of the parallelogram spanned by \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} is \Abs{ \Vect{x} } \Abs{ \Vect{y} }\cdot \sin\sphericalangle( \Vect{x} , \Vect{y} ).
